Nebraskan Brent Zoucha is a hero, and it is my honor to tell his story. pic.twitter.com/tTRXsgQeIP
Brent‚Äôs mother remembers him as an ideal son who loved his life and everyone around him. We cannot thank him enough for his service to our country.
Brent‚Äôs death shocked the central Nebraska community, and during his service, the streets were lined with American Flags and Patriot riders.
On June 9, 2006, Brent and four other Marines came across an IED. Tragically, all of them lost their lives due to the wounds they sustained.

His mother remembers talking on the phone with him in early June and sending him a care package of fig cookies. She didn‚Äôt know it at the time, but that was the last conversation she would have with him. #NEheroes
This area of Iraq saw the majority of its fighting and counterinsurgency from 2004 until 2007. Brent arrived in the heat of battle. #Service

Coincidentally, he was assigned to the exact Marine Corp unit as his older brother. Once Brent arrived to Twentynine Palms, he and his brother found out that they were both deploying to the AL An Bar Province in Iraq.
The extreme discipline that his brother and other Marines routinely displayed greatly interested him. So after graduating from @HPCSTORM he enlisted in the @USMC. #NEheroes
Like many small-town Nebraska boys, Brent spent a lot of time hunting and fishing. He had a special way with animals and even trained a chicken to fly on his shoulder on command.
Brent Zoucha grew up in the small town of Clarks, Nebraska. The youngest of four siblings, his mother described him as having a great smile and always goofing around.
Live Now: https://twitter.com/SenatorFischer/status/1139258016748986368¬†‚Ä¶
